Right, I expect that we’ll have a lot of pre-made feature implementations, where if a plugin provides features A and B, then it can inherit an implementation class to also get feature C for free. But if a plugin can implement feature C more efficiently than our pre-made approach \(for example, a physics engine might cache each model’s CoM calculation\), then it can use its internal implementation instead of our pre-made one.

Or if we want to get really fancy, we can make it so that when a user requests a feature from a plugin, then it will use that plugin’s implementation, but if the plugin doesn’t offer the implementation, then we’ll use the fallback implementation if the plugin provides the features required by the fallback.
